items.description: The tronco is a foot stock made from the trunk of a tree. In Brazil, enslaved men and women were punished by beating them or locking them in these foot stocks. The foot stock in the exhibit was made in Europe, possibly in the Netherlands. It helps tell of the story of Joao, a slave of African descent brought to Brazil by the Portuguese and later escaped to Dutch territory, at some point interrogated and punished by being locked in a tronco like this one. (Source: The Art Newspaper/ Albertine Dijkema)

The kappa is a kettle in which sugarcane juice is boiled. Born into slavery in Suriname, Wally worked in a sugarcane plantation round the clock, using tools like this. Such tools also reflected the craftmanship of the enslaved.  (Source: the Rijksstudio)

Rembrandt wedding portraits of Marten and Oopjen showcases the wealth of the subjects. Marten made his wealth from sugar owing to slave labour in Brazil. He was Oopjen’s first husband; her second fathered a child with an African woman he raped. (Source: Rembrandt, Wikimedia Commons)

Collars like these were worn by black servants in the Netherlands. They were a mark that the wearer was someone’s possession, a trophy rather than a human being. A child servant called Paulus likely wore such a collar. (Source: UVA Public History Humanities blog)

These are some improvised musical instruments from Curacao, part of the tale of Tula. On rare occasions, the enslaved were permitted to gather, and they would make music using improvised instruments. The lead singer would sing, giving their view of current events, and the choir would respond. Through music, news was spread and opinions were shaped. Music was one way that news spread from plantation to plantation as well, which could explain how Tula knew about slave uprisings abroad, inspiring him to lead a revolt in Curacao. He was tortured and killed, but the enslaved he left behind kept his legacy alive through songs.  (Source: Rijksmuseum Slavery: Ten True Stories)

The glass beads help tell the story of Lohkay, an enslaved woman in Sint Maarten who tried to escape and had her breast cut off (earning her the moniker ‘One-Tete Lohkay’). Her bravery inspired others to revolt. The beads were then used as currency by people in slavery and their descendants, but now are worn by residents to ‘signal their connection to their ancestors, and their pride in those who took an independent stance with respect to colonial rules’ (Sint Nicolaas et al., 2020, p. 286). (Source: Rijksmuseum Slavery: Ten True Stories)

Another focal point of the Slavery exhibit was the installation La Bouche du Roi by Beninese artist Romuald Hazoume. This installation honoured the millions of faceless victims of slavery. Jerrycans, each representing an individual, were laid out in the way that enslaved people would be cramped onto a slave vessel. (Source: Rijksmuseum Slavery: Ten True Stories and Open Research Amsterdam)

La Bouche du Roi also included shells, spices, tobacco and mirrors - items Europeans would trade for enslaved people - and alcohol bottles, as people above would drink as people below suffered. The installation was multisensory, including also the scents of tobacco and spices mixed with urine and stool. This brought the experience of the people on these ships closer to the visitor. (Source: Rijksmuseum Slavery: Ten True Stories and Open Research Amsterdam)
